A. Group Assignments

  • Online Judge: 1640
  • Author: SorahISA

Problem Description

PDF

Hints

Hint for Subtask 1: n≤9 (Released 2023.12.11)

Let fn​ denotes the number of ways to partition n people into several segments and gn​ denotes the number of accesses to cost matrix c, we have the transition formula as

fn​=2≤i≤n∑​fn−i​gn​=2≤i≤n∑​gn−i​+fn−i​⋅(2i​)​

and the base cases are fm​=[[m=0]] and gm​=0 for m≤1.

Therefore, if we fix the permutation, there are only f9​=21 ways to partition n people into several segments and g9​=277 accesses to the cost matrix.

Hint for Subtask 1: n≤9 (Released 2023.12.14)

To enumerate all the permutation, we can use the std::next_permutation function:

std::vector<int> perm(n);
// for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) perm[i] = i;
std::iota(begin(perm), end(perm), 0); /// perm = [0, 1, 2, ..., n-1]
do {
    /* do something */
} while (std::next_permutation(begin(perm), end(perm)));

To enumerate all the ways to partition n people into several segments of size ≥2, we can use the following recursive function:

void recur(int n, int last, ...) {
    if (n == last) {
        /// all people are partitioned ///
    }
    else {
        for (int now = last + 2; now <= n; ++now) {
            /// [last, now) is in the same group ///
            recur(n, now, ...);
        }
    }
}

recur(n, 0, ...);
Hint for Subtasks 2, 3: n≤15 (Released 2023.12.18)

Let dp[S] where S⊆[n] denotes the minimum cost to assign all students in S to some group. We can loop through each T⊆[n] and update dp[S∪T] with dp[S]+cost(T).

A dumb way of implementation is to have n dimension of states: dpn dimensions[c1​][c2​][c3​][c4​][…][cn​]​​ where ci​∈{0,1} denotes the state that the ith student is assigned to some group.

  • But we must copy our code for each possible n, and the code would be extremely redundant.

We may also use an std::vector as the state, where we declare dp as std::map<std::vector, int>.

  • This implementation is better than the previous one, but it is still slow.

Observe that ci​∈{0,1}, does it remind you of anything?

Answer

Binary representation of integers.

We may use an integer in [0,2n) to represent the state, where the ith bit of the integer denotes the state of the ith student (whether i∈S).

Remark
  • We can use S & (1 << i) or (S >> i) & 1 to check whether the ith bit of S is on.
  • To check whether S is a subset of T, we can use (S & T) == S or (S | T) == T.
  • To get the complement set of S, we can use S ^ U, where U = (1 << n) - 1 is the mask of n 1's.
Hint for Subtasks 2, 3: n≤15 (Released 2023.12.29)

Let U={1,2,…,n}.
For S⊆U:
    For T⊆U:
        If ∣T∣≥2 and S∩T=∅:
            Update dp[S∪T] with dp[S]+cost(T).

In order for the above algorithm to work, we must ensure that each S is enumerated after we have used all S′⊊S to update dp[S].

The above algorithm works in O(4n⋅poly(n)) since the first and second for loops each has O(2n) iterations.

If the cost is precomputed, the algorithm can run in O(4n).

Hint for Subtasks 3, 4: n≤18 (Released 2023.12.29)

Suppose we can enumerate through only necessary T's, what is the time complexity of the below algorithm?

Let U={1,2,…,n}.
For S⊆U:
    For T⊆U∖S:
        If ∣T∣≥2:
            Update dp[S∪T] with dp[S]+cost(T).

Answer

Consider base-3 representation: the ith position is 0 if i∈S, 1 if i∈T, and 2 if i∈/S∪T. Each (S,T) pair can be represented by a unique base-3 number of length n.

Therefore, we can enumerate through all (S,T) pairs in O(3n).

Sample Code 
int U = (1 << n) - 1;
for (S be the subset of U) { /* and all subset of S is enumerated */
    for (int T = /* complement set of S */; T is non-empty; T = (T-1) & (/* complement set of S */)) {
        if (the number of 1s in T is >= 2) {
            dp[S union T] = min(dp[S union T], dp[S] + cost(T));
        }
    }
}

Line 3 in the above code is the key to enumerate through only necessary T. Please try to understand the code before you proceed.

You can check the bit one by one, or you may check out __builtin_popcount / std::popcount.

Editorial

Solutions

O(4n) -- Enumerate Superset of S 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(4^n)
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

const int INF = INT_MAX >> 1;

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int n; cin >> n;
    unsigned U = (1 << n) - 1;
    
    vector<vector<int>> c(n, vector<int>(n, 0));
    for (auto &vec : c) for (int &x : vec) cin >> x;
    
    vector<int> cost(U+1, 0);
    for (unsigned S = 0; S <= U; ++S) {
        if (popcount(S) == 1) cost[S] = INF;
        else {
            for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {
                if (~S >> i & 1) continue;
                for (int j = i+1; j < n; ++j) {
                    if (~S >> j & 1) continue;
                    cost[S] += c[i][j];
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    vector<int> dp(U+1, INF), fr(U+1, 0);
    dp[0] = 0;
    for (unsigned S = 0; S <= U; ++S) {
        for (unsigned T = S+1; T <= U; ++T) {
            if ((S & T) == 0 and dp[S | T] > dp[S] + cost[T]) {
                dp[S | T] = dp[S] + cost[T];
                fr[S | T] = T;
            }
        }
    }
    
    vector<int> ans(n, 0);
    int tok = 0;
    unsigned now = U;
    while (now) {
        ++tok;
        
        unsigned ids = fr[now];
        while (ids) ans[__lg(ids & -ids)] = tok, ids -= ids & -ids;
        
        now ^= fr[now];
    }
    
    cout << dp.back() << "\n";
    for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) cout << ans[i] << " \n"[i == n-1];
    
    return 0;
}
O(4n) -- Enumerate Subset of S 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(4^n)
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

const int INF = INT_MAX >> 1;

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int n; cin >> n;
    unsigned U = (1 << n) - 1;
    
    vector<vector<int>> c(n, vector<int>(n, 0));
    for (auto &vec : c) for (int &x : vec) cin >> x;
    
    vector<int> cost(U+1, 0);
    for (unsigned S = 0; S <= U; ++S) {
        if (popcount(S) == 1) cost[S] = INF;
        else {
            for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {
                if (~S >> i & 1) continue;
                for (int j = i+1; j < n; ++j) {
                    if (~S >> j & 1) continue;
                    cost[S] += c[i][j];
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    vector<int> dp(U+1, INF), fr(U+1, 0);
    dp[0] = 0;
    for (unsigned S = 1; S <= U; ++S) {
        for (unsigned T = S; T >= 1; --T) {
            if ((S & T) == T and dp[S] > dp[S ^ T] + cost[T]) {
                dp[S] = dp[S ^ T] + cost[T];
                fr[S] = T;
            }
        }
    }
    
    vector<int> ans(n, 0);
    int tok = 0;
    unsigned now = U;
    while (now) {
        ++tok;
        
        unsigned ids = fr[now];
        while (ids) ans[__lg(ids & -ids)] = tok, ids -= ids & -ids;
        
        now ^= fr[now];
    }
    
    cout << dp.back() << "\n";
    for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) cout << ans[i] << " \n"[i == n-1];
    
    return 0;
}
O(2nn2) 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(2^n n^2)
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

const int INF = INT_MAX >> 1;

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int n; cin >> n;
    int U = (1 << n) - 1;
    
    vector<vector<int>> c(n, vector<int>(n));
    for (auto &vec : c) for (int &x : vec) cin >> x;
    
    vector<vector<int>> cost2(n, vector<int>(n));
    vector<vector<vector<int>>> cost3(n, vector<vector<int>>(n, vector<int>(n)));
    for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) for (int j = i+1; j < n; ++j) cost2[i][j] = c[i][j];
    for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) for (int j = i+1; j < n; ++j) for (int k = j+1; k < n; ++k) cost3[i][j][k] = c[i][j] + c[i][k] + c[j][k];
    
    vector<int> dp(U+1, INF), fr(U+1, -1); dp[0] = 0;
    for (int mask = 1; mask <= U; ++mask) {
        int i = __lg(mask & -mask);
        for (int j = i+1; j < n; ++j) {
            if (~mask >> j & 1) continue;
            if (dp[mask] > dp[mask^(1<<i)^(1<<j)] + cost2[i][j]) {
                dp[mask] = dp[mask^(1<<i)^(1<<j)] + cost2[i][j];
                fr[mask] = (1<<i) | (1<<j);
            }
            for (int k = j+1; k < n; ++k) {
                if (~mask >> k & 1) continue;
                if (dp[mask] > dp[mask^(1<<i)^(1<<j)^(1<<k)] + cost3[i][j][k]) {
                    dp[mask] = dp[mask^(1<<i)^(1<<j)^(1<<k)] + cost3[i][j][k];
                    fr[mask] = (1<<i) | (1<<j) | (1<<k);
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    vector<int> ans(n, 0);
    int now = U, tok = 0;
    while (now) {
        ++tok;
        
        int ids = fr[now];
        while (ids) ans[__lg(ids & -ids)] = tok, ids -= ids & -ids;
        
        now ^= fr[now];
    }
    
    cout << dp.back() << "\n";
    for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) cout << ans[i] << " \n"[i == n-1];
    
    return 0;
}

B. Knapsack Problem (Real)

  • Online Judge: 1641
  • Author: SorahISA

Problem Description

PDF

We use C to denote the upper bound of ci​.

Hints

Hint for Subtask 1: C≤20; V≤20 (Released 2023.12.11)

There are only 2V−1 ways to partition V into ordered sequence of positive integers (far less (627 partitions when V=20) if you consider only unordered sequences1).

For example, for V=13, we may check what maximum value of some partition such as (4,1,3,4,1), (13), or (7,1,2,3) may give us.

Please note that each item can be choosed infinite times.

Hint for Subtask 2: C≤100; V≤500 (Released 2023.12.11)

This is a classical problem called "Unbounded Knapsack / 無限背包," you may refer to the internet to find more details (we encourage you to come up with the solution by yourself).

Hint for Subtask 3: C≤100; V≤60000 (Released 2023.12.14; Updated 2023.12.18)

Consider two items with (c1​,v1​) and (c2​,v2​), in which case can we immediately discard item 2? That is, when can we say that item 2 is dominated by item 1?

Answer (Released 2023.12.18)

When c1​≤c2​ and v1​≥v2​.

That is, we can reduce the number of items to O(C) by removing items with same cost but lower value.

Hint for Subtask 4: C≤100 (Released 2023.12.18)

Try to find out the ???​ in the following theorem:

Theorem 1.

  • For the Unbounded-Knapsack problem, the capacity of the knapsack V can be reduced to ???​ by greedily chosing items with maximum CP value.

Lemma 2.

  • Pick any item with maximum CP value, let c′ be its cost.
  • For any (multi)set of items S, if the sum of the costs is k⋅c′, then the items in S can be changed to k copies of the item with maximum CP value and the total profit will not decrease.
  • Furthermore, if S contains any item that does not have the maximum CP value, then the total profit will increase by a positive value.

Lemma 3.

  • For any multiset S⊆[C], if s∈S∑​s≥C2 then there exists an non-empty multiset T⊆S such that t∈T∑​t≡0(modc) for any c∈[1,C].
Hint for Full Solution (Released 2023.12.18)

You may check this blog: https://codeforces.com/blog/entry/98663.

Editorial

Solutions

O(C2logV) -- Knapsack with Binary Exponentiation 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(C^2 log V)
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

#define int int64_t

const int INF = LLONG_MAX >> 1;
const int maxc = 1200 + 5;

struct State {
    
    vector<int> dp;
    
    State () { dp.assign(2 * maxc + 1, 0); }
    
    int& operator [] (int x)       { return dp[x + maxc]; }
    int  operator [] (int x) const { return dp[x + maxc]; }
    
    State operator * (const State &rhs) const {
        const State &lhs = *this;
        State res;
        for (int i = -maxc; i <= maxc; ++i) {
            for (int j = max(-maxc, -maxc-i); j <= min(maxc, maxc-i); ++j) {
                res[i+j] = max(res[i+j], lhs[i] + rhs[j]);
            }
        }
        return res;
    }
    
};

void solve() {
    int n, V; cin >> n >> V;
    
    vector<int> c(n), v(n);
    for (int &x : c) cin >> x;
    for (int &x : v) cin >> x;
    
    vector<int> best(maxc, 0);
    for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) best[c[i]] = max(best[c[i]], v[i]);
    
    State base, ans;
    for (int i = 0; i <= 2*maxc; ++i) {
        for (int j = 1; j <= min(i, maxc-1); ++j) {
            base.dp[i] = max(base.dp[i], base.dp[i-j] + best[j]);
        }
    }
    for (int i = -maxc; i <= maxc; ++i) ans[i] = (i < 0 ? -INF : base[i - maxc]);
    
    // assert(base.dp == (ans * base).dp);
    
    int exp = V / maxc;
    while (exp) {
        if (exp & 1) ans = ans * base;
        exp >>= 1, base = base * base;
    }
    
    cout << ans[V % maxc] << "\n";
}

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int t = 1; cin >> t;
    for (int _ = 1; _ <= t; ++_) {
        solve();
    }
    
    return 0;
}
1

https://oeis.org/A000041

C. Longest Common Subsequence

  • Online Judge: 1642
  • Author: SorahISA

Problem Description

PDF

Hints

Hint for Subtask 1: n≤16 (Released 2023.12.11)

Seeing that n≤16, you may want to enumerate all subsequences a′ of a.

After fixing a′, how can you choose b′, a subsequence of b, efficiently such that ai′​=bi′​?

Answer

Greedy. Pick if you can.

You may come up with some claims easily, but the important thing is: Can you prove that the greedy algorithm always produce the optimal solution?

Hint for Subtask 2: n≤1000 (Released 2023.12.14)

Recall the real Longest Common Subsequence problem taught in class. The state definition of the problem is as follows:

dp[i][j]=the length of the LCS of a[1…i] and b[1…j]dp[i][j]=max⎩⎨⎧​i′≤i and j′≤j(i′,j′)=(i,j)​max​{dp[i′][j′]},i′<i and j′<jmax​{dp[i′][j′]}+1,​if we don’t pair a[i] with b[j]if a[i]=b[j] and we pair a[i] with b[j]​​

Since dp[i][j]≥dp[i′][j′] for all i′≤i and j′≤j, dp[i−1][j] and dp[i][j−1] dominates all other options in the first case, and dp[i−1][j−1] dominates all other options in the second case. Therefore, we can simplify the state definition as follows:

dp[i][j]=max{max{dp[i−1][j],dp[i][j−1]},dp[i−1][j−1]+1,​if we don’t pair a[i] with b[j]if a[i]=b[j] and we pair a[i] with b[j]​

The base cases are dp[0][j]=dp[i][0]=0 for all i and j, and the answer is dp[n][n].

This problem is similar to the real LCS problem, can you modify the state definition and the transition formula above to solve this problem?

Hint for Subtask 3: n≤40000 (Released 2023.12.18; Updated 2023.12.29)

What is the minimum length of the LCS? Can you come up with any a and b to achieve this minimum length?

Answer (Released 2023.12.29)

The minimum length of the LCS is n−⌊n​⌋.

For the proof (and the construction), you may consider the path from (0,0) to (n,n) in the DP table: How many obstacles do you need to make the answer always ≤n−k?

Hint for Subtask 3: n≤40000 (Released 2023.12.29)

Your path from (0,0) to (n,n) in the DP table will not diverge too much from the diagonal line x=y.

Hint for Full Solution (Released 2023.12.29)

Consider turning the DP table by 45∘, what do you see?

Hint for Full Solution (Released 2023.12.29)

Do you think that dp[i][∗] and dp[i+1][∗] look similar? Can you find a way to compute dp[i+1][∗] from dp[i][∗] in Θ(logn) or Θ(1) time?

Editorial

Solutions

O(n2) -- Simple DP Formula 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(n^2)
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

void solve() {
    int n; cin >> n;
    
    vector<int> a(n), b(n);
    for (int &x : a) cin >> x;
    for (int &x : b) cin >> x;
    
    vector<vector<int>> dp(n+1, vector<int>(n+1, 0));
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; ++i) {
        for (int j = 1; j <= n; ++j) {
            dp[i][j] = max({
                dp[i][j-1],
                dp[i-1][j],
                dp[i-1][j-1] + (a[i-1] != b[j-1])
            });
        }
    }
    
    vector<pair<int, int>> ans;
    {
        int nx = n, ny = n;
        while (nx and ny) {
                 if (dp[nx][ny] == dp[nx][ny-1]) --ny;
            else if (dp[nx][ny] == dp[nx-1][ny]) --nx;
            else ans.emplace_back(a[--nx], b[--ny]);
        }
        reverse(begin(ans), end(ans));
    }
    
    int m = dp[n][n];
    cout << m << "\n";
    for (int i = 0; i < m; ++i) cout << ans[i].first  << " \n"[i == m-1];
    for (int i = 0; i < m; ++i) cout << ans[i].second << " \n"[i == m-1];
}

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int t = 1; cin >> t;
    for (int _ = 1; _ <= t; ++_) {
        solve();
    }
    
    return 0;
}
O(nn​) -- Changing DP State 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(n^1.5)
 * - The minimum answer is n - floor(sqrt(n)).
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

const int INF = INT_MAX >> 1;

void solve() {
    int n; cin >> n;
    int sqn = int(ceil(sqrtl(n))) + 5;
    
    vector<int> a(n), b(n);
    for (int &x : a) cin >> x;
    for (int &x : b) cin >> x;
    
    vector<vector<int>> dp(n+1, vector<int>(sqn+1, INF));
    for (int j = 0; j <= sqn; ++j) dp[0][j] = 0;
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; ++i) {
        dp[i][0] = dp[i-1][0] + 1 + (dp[i-1][0] < n and a[i-1] == b[dp[i-1][0]]);
        for (int j = 1; j <= sqn; ++j) {
            dp[i][j] = min(
                dp[i-1][j-1],
                dp[i-1][j] + 1 + (dp[i-1][j] < n and a[i-1] == b[dp[i-1][j]])
            );
        }
    }
    
    for (int j = 0; j <= sqn; ++j) {
        if (dp[n][j] > n) continue;
        
        int nx = n, ny = j;
        vector<pair<int, int>> ans;
        while (nx) {
            if (ny and dp[nx][ny] == dp[nx-1][ny-1]) --nx, --ny;
            else ans.emplace_back(a[nx-1], b[dp[nx][ny]-1]), --nx;
        }
        reverse(begin(ans), end(ans));
        
        cout << n - j << "\n";
        for (int i = 0; i < n-j; ++i) cout << ans[i].first  << " \n"[i == n-j-1];
        for (int i = 0; i < n-j; ++i) cout << ans[i].second << " \n"[i == n-j-1];
        
        break;
    }
}

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int t = 1; cin >> t;
    for (int _ = 1; _ <= t; ++_) {
        solve();
    }
    
    return 0;
}
O(n) -- Observing DP Properties 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(n)
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

void solve() {
    int n; cin >> n;
    
    vector<int> a(n+1), b(n+1), inv(n+1), bar(n+1);
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; ++i) cin >> a[i], inv[a[i]] = i;
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; ++i) cin >> b[i], bar[inv[b[i]]] = i;
    
    vector<pair<int, int>> dp(2*n+1); /// [-n, n]
    vector<pair<int, int>> fr(n+2, {0, 0}); /// [2, n+1]
    for (int i = 0; i <= n; ++i) dp[i - 0 + n] = {0, i + 0};
    for (int j = 1; j <= n; ++j) dp[0 - j + n] = {0, 0 + j};
    
    for (int i = 2; i <= n+1; ++i) {
        int j = bar[i-1] + 1;
        auto [val_u, lst_u] = dp[(i-1) - j + n]; val_u += ((i-1) + j - lst_u) / 2;
        auto [val_l, lst_l] = dp[i - (j-1) + n]; val_l += (i + (j-1) - lst_l) / 2;
        if (val_u >= val_l) dp[i - j + n] = {val_u, i + j}, fr[i] = {-1, 0};
        else                dp[i - j + n] = {val_l, i + j}, fr[i] = {0, -1};
    }
    
    auto [val, lst] = dp[n - n + n]; val += (n + n - lst) / 2;
    int m = val;
    vector<pair<int, int>> ans;
    
    {
        int i = n+1, j = n+1;
        while (i > 1 and j > 1) {
            if (bar[i-1] == j-1) {
                auto [di, dj] = fr[i];
                i += di, j += dj;
            }
            else {
                --i, --j;
                if (i and j) ans.emplace_back(a[i], b[j]);
            }
        }
        reverse(begin(ans), end(ans));
    }
    
    cout << m << "\n";
    for (int i = 0; i < m; ++i) cout << ans[i].first  << " \n"[i == m-1];
    for (int i = 0; i < m; ++i) cout << ans[i].second << " \n"[i == m-1];
}

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int t = 1; cin >> t;
    for (int _ = 1; _ <= t; ++_) {
        solve();
    }
    
    return 0;
}

D. Longest Increasing Subsequence

  • Online Judge: 1643
  • Author: SorahISA

Problem Description

PDF

Hints

General Hint (Released 2023.12.29)

Try projecting the problem to a 2D plane, where the x-axis is i and the y-axis is a[i].

This may help you understand more about the problem.

Hint for Subtask 1: n≤15 (Released 2023.12.11)

Seeing that n≤15, you may want to enumerate all subset S of [n]:={1,2,…,n}.

The only thing left is to check a subsequence's validness.

Hint for Subtask 1: n≤15 (Released 2023.12.14)

There are several method to enumerate all subset S of [n].

  1. n layers of for loops: ???
  2. Recursion: using DFS-like recursion is helpful when you want to improve the time complexity by O(n).
  3. Bitmasks: it is the fastest and is the most simple one to write.
for (int mask = 0; mask < (1<<n); ++mask) { /// (1<<n) is 2**n
    vector<int> subset;
    for (int bit = 0; bit < n; ++bit) {
        /// check if the i-th bit is 1 ///
        // if (mask & (1 << bit)) subset.emplace_back(bit);
        if ((mask >> bit) & 1) subset.emplace_back(bit);
    }
    /* do something */
}

For a subset S to be valid, we need to check:

  1. S is increasing: a[s0​]≤a[s1​]≤⋯≤a[sk−1​].
  2. S is valid: ∀i∈[1,k−1], ∄p∈(si−1​,si​) such that a[si−1​]≤a[p]≤a[si​].
Hint for Subtask 2: n≤200 (Released 2023.12.18; Updated 2023.12.29)

We may use dp[i] to denote the number of the maximal increasing subsequences (MIS) of [a[0],a[1],…,a[i]].

What is the necessary and sufficient condition for dp[j] to transition to dp[i]?

Answer (Released 2023.12.29)

Consider the following state: "dp[i] denotes the MIS count ending at a[i]," which position j may become the second to last number in the MIS?

  • 0≤j<i, since the second to last number must be in the left of a[i].
  • a[j]≤a[i], since the second to last number must be smaller than a[i].
  • ∄k∈(j,i):a[k]∈[a[j],a[i]], since the sequence must be maximal.

From here, you might come up with an O(n3) brute force solution which loops through i, j, and k.

Hint for Subtask 3: n≤2000 (Released 2023.12.29)

If you enumerate j in some specific order, you may find that the third condition can be checked in O(1).

Hint for Subtask 4: a[i]≤15 (Released 2023.12.29)

Since a[i]≤15, there are not many transitions for each dp[i].

Proof.

Consider 0≤x<y<i where a[x]=a[y], then dp[x] is not a valid transition for dp[i] since the third condition is violated when k=y.

Editorial

Solutions

O(n3) -- Calculating Sum with one DP 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(n^3)
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

using i64 = long long;

const i64 mod = 1'000'000'007;

void solve() {
    int N; cin >> N;
    
    vector<i64> A(N+2), nA(N+2);
    for (int i = 1; i <= N; ++i) cin >> A[i], nA[N+1-i] = mod - A[i];
    A[0] = 0, A[N+1] = mod;
    
    vector<pair<i64, i64>> dp(N+2, {0, 0});
    dp[0] = {1, 0};
    for (int i = 1; i <= N+1; ++i) {
        for (int j = 0; j < i; ++j) {
            if (A[j] > A[i]) continue;
            bool valid = true;
            for (int k = j+1; k <= i-1; ++k) {
                if (A[j] <= A[k] and A[k] <= A[i]) valid = false;
            }
            if (valid) {
                dp[i].first = (dp[i].first + dp[j].first) % mod;
                dp[i].second = (dp[i].second + dp[j].second + dp[j].first * A[i]) % mod;
            }
        }
    }
    
    i64 cnt = dp[N+1].first, sum = dp[N+1].second;
    cout << cnt << " " << sum << "\n";
}

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int t = 1; cin >> t;
    for (int _ = 1; _ <= t; ++_) {
        solve();
    }
    
    return 0;
}
O(n3) -- Calculating Sum with two DPs 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(n^3)
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

using i64 = long long;

const int INF = 1'000'000'000 + 5;
const i64 mod = 1'000'000'007;

vector<i64> solve_dp(int N, vector<i64> A) {
    vector<i64> dp(N+2, 0);
    dp[0] = 1;
    for (int i = 1; i <= N+1; ++i) {
        for (int j = 0; j < i; ++j) {
            if (A[j] > A[i]) continue;
            bool valid = true;
            for (int k = j+1; k <= i-1; ++k) {
                if (A[j] <= A[k] and A[k] <= A[i]) valid = false;
            }
            if (valid) dp[i] = (dp[i] + dp[j]) % mod;
        }
    }
    return dp;
}

void solve() {
    int N; cin >> N;
    
    vector<i64> A(N+2), nA(N+2);
    for (int i = 1; i <= N; ++i) cin >> A[i], nA[N+1-i] = INF - A[i];
    A[0] = nA[0] = 0, A[N+1] = nA[N+1] = INF;
    
    vector<i64> dp = solve_dp(N, A);
    vector<i64> ndp = solve_dp(N, nA);
    reverse(begin(ndp), end(ndp));
    
    i64 cnt = dp[N+1], sum = 0;
    for (int i = 1; i <= N; ++i) sum = (sum + dp[i] * ndp[i] % mod * A[i]) % mod;
    cout << cnt << " " << sum << "\n";
}

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int t = 1; cin >> t;
    for (int _ = 1; _ <= t; ++_) {
        solve();
    }
    
    return 0;
}
O(nlog2n) -- DP with Divide and Conquer 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(n log^2 n)
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

#define int int64_t

const int INF = 1'000'000'000 + 5;
const int mod = 1'000'000'007;

struct ID {
    int a, i, sum;
    ID (int _a, int _i, int _sum) :
        a(_a), i(_i), sum(_sum) {}
    bool operator < (const ID &rhs) { return a > rhs.a; }
};

vector<int> solve_dp(int N, vector<int> A) {
    
    vector<pair<int, int>> disc;
    for (int i = 0; i <= N+1; ++i) disc.emplace_back(A[i], i);
    sort(begin(disc), end(disc));
    
    vector<int> _id(N+2);
    for (int i = 0; i <= N+1; ++i) {
        A[i] = lower_bound(begin(disc), end(disc), pair{A[i], i}) - begin(disc);
        _id[A[i]] = i;
    }
    
    vector<int> dp(N+2, 0); dp[0] = 1;
    
    function<void(vector<int>, int, int)> recur = [&](vector<int> id, int L, int R) {
        if (L == R) return;
        
        int M = (L + R) >> 1;
        vector<int> id_L, id_R;
        for (int i : id) (i <= M ? id_L : id_R).emplace_back(i);
        recur(id_L, L, M);
        
        deque<ID> stk_L; /// (a[i], i, prefix_sum)
        deque<int> stk_R; /// (i)
        for (int i : id) {
            if (i <= M) {
                /// maintain stk with increasing a[i] and decreasing i ([0] is smallest) ///
                while (stk_L.size() and i > stk_L[0].i) stk_L.pop_front();
                stk_L.emplace_front(A[i], i, (stk_L.size() ? stk_L[0].sum : 0) + dp[i]);
            }
            else {
                /// maintain stk with increasing a[i] and increasing i ([0] is largest) ///
                while (stk_R.size() and i < stk_R[0]) stk_R.pop_front();
                /// query stk_L range sum (back, stk_R[0]) ///
                if (stk_L.size()) {
                    auto it = lower_bound(begin(stk_L), end(stk_L), ID{(stk_R.size() ? A[stk_R[0]] : -1), 0, 0});
                    // while (it != begin(stk_L)) {
                    //     it = prev(it);
                    //     dp[i] = (dp[i] + dp[it->i]) % mod;
                    //     debug(i, it->i);
                    // }
                    int cnt = (stk_L[0].sum - (it != end(stk_L) ? it->sum : 0)) % mod;
                    dp[i] = (dp[i] + cnt) % mod;
                }
                stk_R.emplace_front(i);
            }
        }
        
        recur(id_R, M+1, R);
    };
    recur(_id, 0, N+1);
    
    return dp;
}

void solve() {
    int N; cin >> N;
    
    vector<int> A(N+2), nA(N+2);
    for (int i = 1; i <= N; ++i) cin >> A[i], nA[N+1-i] = INF - A[i];
    A[0] = nA[0] = 0, A[N+1] = nA[N+1] = INF;
    
    vector<int> dp = solve_dp(N, A);
    vector<int> ndp = solve_dp(N, nA);
    reverse(begin(ndp), end(ndp));
    
    int cnt = dp[N+1], sum = 0;
    for (int i = 1; i <= N; ++i) sum = (sum + dp[i] * ndp[i] % mod * A[i]) % mod;
    cout << cnt << " " << sum << "\n";
}

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int t = 1; cin >> t;
    for (int _ = 1; _ <= t; ++_) {
        solve();
    }
    
    return 0;
}

E. Maximum Sum Path

  • Online Judge: 1644
  • Author: SorahISA

Problem Description

PDF

Hints

Hint for Subtask 1: n≤5; m≤10 (Released 2023.12.11)

m is very small, in this case we may implement an algorithm that enumerates all permutations of the edges and check the validness of the path.

Keyword: std::next_permutation

Hint for Subtask 2: n≤500; m≤2000 (Released 2023.12.18; Updated 2023.12.29)

If we are not constrained by the given graph, let's try treating the states as nodes and the transitions as edges, creating a new graph.

Consider a graph with 2n nodes 1B​,1W​,2B​,2W​,…,nB​,nW​, where iB​ denotes the state where the last edge you walked is black, and iW​ vice versa.

How do we connect the nodes? How can the constraint "It is guaranteed that even with an infinite number of stars, it is not possible to traverse this graph infinitely" help?

Answer (Released 2023.12.29)

In the new graph, we create an edge (ic1​​,jc2​​,w) if and only if there is an edge (i,j,c2​,w).

The constraint means that there is no cycle in the new graph. In other words, the new graph is a directed acyclic graph (DAG).

Hint for Full Solution (Released 2023.12.29)

The problem now (almost) boils down to "finding the longest path in a DAG," which is a classical problem in dynamic programming.

Editorial

Solutions

O(n+m) -- Finding Longest Path on DAG 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(n+m)
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

const int INF = INT_MAX >> 1;

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int n, m; cin >> n >> m;
    
    vector<int> l(n);
    for (int &x : l) cin >> x;
    
    vector<vector<pair<int, int>>> adj(2*n+1);
    vector<int> deg_i(2*n+1, 0), vis(2*n+1, 0);
    for (int i = 0; i < 2*n; ++i) {
        if (l[i>>1] == 0) adj[2*n].emplace_back(i, 0),    ++deg_i[i];
        else              adj[2*n].emplace_back(i, -INF), ++deg_i[i];
    }
    for (int i = 0; i < m; ++i) {
        int u, v, w; char c; cin >> u >> v >> c >> w, --u, --v;
        if (c == 'B') adj[u<<1].emplace_back(v<<1|1, w), ++deg_i[v<<1|1];
        if (c == 'W') adj[u<<1|1].emplace_back(v<<1, w), ++deg_i[v<<1];
    }
    
    vector<int> ans(n, 0);
    vector<int> dp(2*n+1, 0);
    function<void(int)> dag_dp = [&](int now) {
        for (auto [x, star] : adj[now]) {
            dp[x] = max(dp[x], dp[now] + star);
            if (++vis[x] == deg_i[x]) {
                ans[x>>1] = max(ans[x>>1], dp[x]);
                if (dp[x] < l[x>>1]) dp[x] = -INF;
                dag_dp(x);
            }
        }
    };
    dag_dp(2*n);
    
    for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) cout << ans[i] << " \n"[i == n-1];
    
    return 0;
}

F. Counting Paths on a Graph

  • Online Judge: 1645
  • Author: SorahISA

Problem Description

PDF

Hints

Hint for Subtask 1: n≤10; m=0 (Released 2023.12.11)

Here is the graph for n=10:

There are only 17 edges even when n=10, you may try to enumerate each subset of the edges and check whether they form an exciting route.

Hint for Subtask 1: n≤10; m=0 (Released 2023.12.15)

For subset of edges to form an exciting route, we need to check:

  1. The length of the edges are all different.
  2. If we sort the edges by their length, the ith edge is connected to the (i+1)th edge.

These two conditions are necessary and sufficient.

Hint for Subtask 4: n≤400 (Released 2023.12.18)

The only two things that matter are the last visited vertex u and the absolute difference between the last two verices ∣u−v∣.

How may the state be defined? What is the transition between states? In what order should we update the DP tables?

Editorial

Solutions

O(nlogn+mlogm) 
/**
 * Time Complexity: O(n log n + m log m)
**/

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

signed main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0), cin.tie(0);
    
    int N, M, mod; cin >> N >> M >> mod;
    
    vector<tuple<int, int, int>> edges(M);
    for (auto &[s, u, v] : edges) cin >> u >> v, s = v - u;
    sort(begin(edges), end(edges));
    
    vector<int> dp[2];
    dp[0].assign(N+1, 1), dp[0][0] = 0;
    dp[1].assign(N+1, 0);
    
    auto modadd = [&](int x, int y) -> int { return (x + y >= mod ? x + y - mod : x + y); };
    
    for (int step = 1, tok1 = 0, tok2 = 0; step <= N; ++step) {
        
        for (int i = step; i <= N; i += step) dp[1][i] = modadd((i+step <= N ? dp[0][i+step] : 0), dp[0][i-step]);
        while (tok1 < M and get<0>(edges[tok1]) == step) {
            auto [s, u, v] = edges[tok1++];
            dp[1][v] = modadd(dp[1][v], dp[0][u]);
            dp[1][u] = modadd(dp[1][u], dp[0][v]);
        }
        
        for (int i = step; i <= N; i += step) dp[0][i] = modadd(dp[0][i], dp[1][i]), dp[1][i] = 0;
        while (tok2 < tok1) {
            auto [s, u, v] = edges[tok2++];
            dp[0][v] = modadd(dp[0][v], dp[1][v]), dp[1][v] = 0;
            dp[0][u] = modadd(dp[0][u], dp[1][u]), dp[1][u] = 0;
        }
        
    }
    
    int ans = mod - N;
    for (int i = 1; i <= N; ++i) ans = modadd(ans, dp[0][i]);
    cout << ans << "\n";
    
    return 0;
}

G. Rod Cutting

  • Online Judge: 1646
  • Author: SorahISA

Problem Description

PDF

Hints

Hint for Subtask 1: n≤6 (Released 2023.12.11)

Since 3n≤18, you may come up with a O(23npoly(n)) solution, but this is infeasible for the later subtasks.

Maybe you can try another state definition? What are the minimal requirements for a cutting plan to be valid?

Hint: The intended time complexity for this subtask is O((3n)7), which runs suprisingly fast.

Hint for Subtask 1: n≤6 (Released 2023.12.15)

You may start with the state like f(L)=f(a)+f(L−a)+cutting cost, but it is not enough if we only keep track of the length of the current rod, as the cutting cost may differ depending on the position of the cut.

Answer

A better way is to keep track of the both endpoints of the current rod, so that you know the position of the cut.

g(L,R)=g(L,m)+g(m,R)+cm​+C⋅(R−L).

But this definition is still not enough, as we need to know whether the rods can be packed into n bags of rods which lengths sum up to 3 meters each.

Hint for Subtask 1: n≤6 (Released 2023.12.15; Updated 2023.12.18)

Observe that after cutting, the rod will be divided into several subsegments with length ≤3.

Since we must pack the rods into n bags of rods which lengths sum up to 3 meters each, the length of rods in each bag are either

  1. three length 1 rods,
  2. one length 1 rod and one length 2 rod, or
  3. one length 3 rod.
Answer (Released 2023.12.18)

So we may define the state as dp[ℓ][r][c1​][c2​], where

  • ℓ and r are the left and right endpoints of the current rod, and
  • c1​ and c2​ are the number of subsegments of length 1 and 2.
